messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:49): wow these videos are really interesting
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (09:51): what videos?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:52): http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2007Sep/0103.html
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (09:53): yeah, actual user testing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:02): man this is so interesting
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:03): in the first 10 minutes of the table video it seems the biggest problems are with a bug jaws has about colspan/rowspan
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:03): also interesting with the budget table is that it's clear that the headers being read out are completely useless
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:03): it's not reading the column header
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:05): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: also, JAWS has pretty significant trouble with thousand separators that are commonplace
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:07): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: yeah, the number handling is appalling in that instance
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:07): notice he goes to the horrific configuration UI
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:07): and does far better than I (a sighted user) did when I went there!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:08): i think that revenue table (http://www.wisc.edu/about/facts/budget.php#budgetRev) is an example of a table that is badly marked up with headers=""
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:08): "source" shouldn't be on the headers="" list for the data cells
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:08): and that table uses abbr="" in a really confusing way, too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:09): "amount state revenue source. 151.8 column 2" is not a useful way of showing that data.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:12): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: what would you do better (apart from striking "source" from the speech)?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:13): "source" is a header for first column, it shouldn't be given as a header for the data cells
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:13): headers aren't transitive
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:14): arguably the "state revenue" row shouldn't be a header for anything but the first column either
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:14): though scope="" can't represent that while still keeping the row table-wide
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:14): which is interesting

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:15): with VoiceOver, I found that due to lack of easy documentation and due to the aural UI features being undiscoverable without docs, it is really hard for a person who isn't a routine user to check if something works in a sane way
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:15): i think you'd want that first data cell read out as "255.1 millions of dollars, general program appropriations, state revenue"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:16): second cell as "-1.7 percent change from previous year, general program appropriations, state revenue"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:17): though how you decide that the top header comes first, then the left header, then the sub-top header, i dunno
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:17): on the next table you'd want it the other way around

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:17): second data cell on http://broads-authority.gov.uk/boating/navigating/tide-tables.html you'd want to read out as "1.69 meters, high water, wednesday 5th, september"
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:17): I've only watched the first two videos so far
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:18): and I think they demonstrate that "row" and "column" aren't the real scopes but "right" and "down"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:22): yeah that's basically what html5 does
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:23): (though it uses the row/column names)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:23): the federal bank table example is interesting, it's a table that uses scope but that shows jaws7 not supporting it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:23): it also shows that jaws has some heuristics to read out the first column even with no markup for it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:24): woah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:24): the immediate reaction to the first table with summary="" information is "i'm wondering how necessary is that."
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:27): also, it shows how the insistence on cultural variance in date and number formats is an accessibility problem
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:29): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:29): go <time>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:29): not sure what to do about numbers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:29): <n> seems excessive and unlikely to be widely used
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:29): i'd rather test the waters with <time> first
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:29): there's no way normal authors who are accustomed to type in Word would stop and mark up their numbers as numbers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:30): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:30): same could be said of dates though
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:30): I suppose having a comma, period or nbsp every three digits could match a heuristic pattern
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:31): or apostrophe
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:31): but dealing with non-nbsp regular spaces would be hard
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:31): you could use lang to infer the likely number format
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:32): everything would be so much easier if all nationalistic vive la difference could be put aside here
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:32): or just try to recognize a bunch of widely used number formats
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:32): but I guess some are ambiguous
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:32): 1.001 - is that just over 1, or just over 1000?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:33): you're not going to get france or the uk to change to 1,001 or 1.001 respectively
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:33): (or vice versa)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:33): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: to some extent yes. but there are a lot of people who use English together with ISO dates, SI units and 24 hour clock for international communications
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:33): (in fact, it annoys me that legacy English date-time stuff comes with the English UI language on many systems)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:35): https://bugs.maemo.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1968 for instance
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:35): there's also wide disagreement on the right way to do quotation marks but that seems less of a practical problem
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:36): systems would benefit from a U.S. English plus metric/ISO "locale"

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:16): (on the HTTP server when examining incoming requests)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:19): case-sensitive it is
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:19): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: they're case sensitive and, I believe, all existing methods (GET, POST, etc.) should be uppercase
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:43): is there a best practice for transferring long non-ASCII strings in HTTP headers?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:43): or should I just steer clear and do something else?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:44): hmm. you could use %-encoding, but that's really only for URIs
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:45): what are you trying to do?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:46): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I'm considering whether I should allow validator parameters as HTTP headers as opposed to query string params in the POST Web service API
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:46): what HTTP headers are you trying to use for that?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:47): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Content-Location for doc=
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:47): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: the others would have to be X-Foo-Or-Bar
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:47): the potentially non-ASCII value would be schema IRIs
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:48): you might be better off just using a query string
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:48): which I could force to be URIs
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:48): well, let's see if I can get away with query string only
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:53): if a query string doesn't meet your needs, you could also try POSTing JSON or XML or something n the request body
